title: In Poland, politics cuts across the dinner table
text:
KOBYLIN-BORZYMY, Poland — As Poland prepares for a general election later this month, some in the country are worried about the impact it will have — on their relationships with their families.

Take Marta, a 40-year-old project manager from Warsaw who doesn't want to give her real name out of fear of worsening her already damaged relationship with her parents.

Following an argument about Polish politics after one of the nationalist independence marches backed by the government, Marta and her parents didn’t speak for a year and a half. “No greetings for Christmas, no texts on my birthday, nothing,” she said.

Marta supports defending the rights of homosexuals, immigrants and people of color. Her parents, she said, are “right-wing,” and they praise every move of Poland’s conservative ruling Law and Justice (PiS) party.

“We started to talk about a political reform, and then we ended with that I’m a disgrace for the family, how could I grow up like this, that my partner should cut my throat and other nice choice words,” she said. "Coming from both sides, to be fair."

“The worst thing this government has done to us is that it divided people” — Kasia, PR manager from Warsaw

Marta’s divided family isn’t the only one. As the rival campaigns ramp up their outreach ahead of the vote on October 13, Poles are being increasingly asked to pick sides in what's more than a simple political spat.

As is the case in an increasing number of countries — France, the United States, the United Kingdom — politics in Poland cuts not so much along the traditional party lines of the 20th century but along new divisions: “liberal” vs. “illiberal,” “urban,” vs. “rural,” “patriotic” vs. “democratic.”

It's a split that cuts as much across the dinner table as across different parts of the country. “This dispute goes down ... to the institutions and the society,” said Andrzej Rychard, a sociologist with the Polish Academy of Sciences.

Divided country

A study published this year by the University of Warsaw’s Center for Research on Prejudice found supporters of Poland’s ruling and opposition parties hold strikingly negative feelings toward each other. The antagonism is sharper among the opposition parties.

“For some time I believed talking about ‘two Polands’ was exaggerated and simplified,” said Rychard. “I thought statements like, 'It cuts across the family table, that you can’t come to an agreement during a family birthday,' was a bit of mythology.” No longer.

For many in the country, however, it's a reality.

“The worst thing this government has done to us is that it divided people,” said Kasia, a 30 year-old PR manager from Warsaw. She said she lost contact with several friends after disagreements on issues like migration policy.

Zuzanna, who lives in the U.S., said she hadn’t visited her family during her last trip to Poland, thanks to disagreements over women's rights.

Even while abroad, they’d argued over Polish politics on Facebook. "[The situation in Poland] is much worse than in the U.S. because here the minorities have 'tasted' their rights, respect and they know they can demand them," she said.

Medical student Krzysztof said he’d minimized contact with his parents, because they don’t accept his LGBT friends. "[Since Law and Justice came to power] the public media have very intensively promoted a version of the world, where only their true Christian values are constantly threatened and attacked, which goes in line with what my parents think," he said. "Since then they've been much more certain of their rights and it's much more difficult to explain something to them or even to have a conversation."

Political debate in Poland today is less an argument over the country’s future than “two semantically closed universes," said Radosław Markowski, a professor at Warsaw's University of Social Sciences and Humanities.

Rather than criticizing an opponent’s policies, Poles now attack their interlocutor's legitimacy, he said. “The degenerated language, in this seemingly homogenous country, is one of the biggest challenges for the quality of Polish democracy,” he said. “This is the narrative of contempt and aversion.”

“The intensity of this conflict is very strong, stronger than in other European countries.”

Talk turns to violence

The depth of the growing schism is perhaps most obvious in the socially liberal city of Gdańsk, in northern Poland, where an opposition coalition outpolled PiS 60 percent to 26 percent in May’s European Parliament election.

The city was shaken by the January murder of Mayor Paweł Adamowicz. His assailant was a mentally ill former convict who blamed Adamowicz’s Civic Platform party for his imprisonment.

After the tragedy, the whole country grieved, but not for long. Some PiS supporters have taken to calling the city a “German republic,” claiming its citizens aren’t “real Poles,” and dubbed new Mayor Aleksandra Dulkiewicz “Frau Dulkiewicz.”

In July, the magazine W sieci, which generally supports the ruling party, published an issue featuring Nazi swastikas and portraits of Adamowicz, Dulkiewicz and European Council President Donald Tusk (another Gdańsk native) with the headline: “Does Gdańsk want to join Germany?”

“We can see there’s a social division,” Dulkiewicz said, sitting by a high window on the 33rd floor of an office tower overlooking nearby shipyards and the Baltic Sea. She cites her own efforts to lobby Poland’s culture minister, Piotr Gliński, after the government refused to fund a new cultural center in the city, the European Solidarity Center, devoted to the history of the Solidarity movement.

“It was a very difficult conversation ... His understanding of the word 'solidarity' was totally different to mine,” she said, adding that she wanted to look to the future while his frame of reference was the historical Solidarity labor movement that helped bring down communism decades ago.

While Dulkiewicz is trying to calm social tensions, not all government opponents are doing the same. There's a sense of rage and frustration among parts of the liberal opposition when they look at PiS's stubbornly high opinion poll numbers.

A Civic Platform Senator Jerzy Wcisła called PiS voters “plebs” while judge Jerzy Stępień referred to them as “feudal peasants.”

Resentment at this type of language is palpable in PiS strongholds. In Kobylin-Borzymy, a county of 3,000 nestled amid cornfields in northeast Poland, the ruling party won 85 percent in the last general election. Non-partisan Mayor Dariusz Sikorski has experience with journalists coming to find “typical PiS voters.”

“Please don’t say that our people are stupid,” he said — more than once. “People here simply have their values. They respect the land and they respect the family. It doesn’t do any harm to anyone.”

Rychard, the sociologist, is nevertheless hopeful. Poles are getting richer, better educated, more secular and pro-European, he said. That should, in theory, shift the country toward the political center.

“In a long perspective, these processes will inevitably blur this dual Poland,” he said.

But that's not going to have much immediate impact on PiS's electoral fortunes.
description: Divisions deepen as the country heads to the polls on October 13.
